chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Lactational amenorrhea method
chapter.summary: Covers advice on using the lactational amenorrhoea method, the advantages, disadvantages, risks, and efficacy.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 13 years to 60 years (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I assess a woman who is planning to use the lactational amenorrhoea method of contraception?
subChapters.htmlStringContent: • For information on how to assess a woman who is planning to use the lactational amenorrhea method of contraception, see the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice should I give a woman who is considering using the lactational amenorrhoea method of contraception?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Provide advice and information about:
    • The conditions needed for the method to be reliable. See the section on The lactational amenorrhea method (LAM).
    • The advantages, disadvantages, and risks of the LAM. See the section on What are the advantages, disadvantages, and risks of the lactational amenorrhoea method?
    • The efficacy of the LAM. See the section on How effective is the lactational amenorrhoea method at preventing pregnancy?
      • Inform the woman that the effect of expressing milk on the efficacy of the LAM is not known, but it may be reduced.
    • Comparative efficacy of alternative methods of contraception. See the section on Comparative efficacy of contraceptive methods in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.
  • Advise the woman that an alternative contraceptive method should be started when any of the following occur:
    • Her menstrual periods return (bleeding in the first 8 weeks after childbirth is not considered menstrual bleeding).
    • She stops fully or nearly fully breastfeeding.
      • A woman is no longer fully, or nearly fully breastfeeding, if the baby is getting less than 85% of its feeds as breast milk.
    • Weaning (starting solids) begins.
    • Her baby is 6 months old.
  • If the woman has a condition which makes pregnancy an unacceptable risk, advise her that the LAM may not be appropriate for her, as alternative contraceptive methods have lower failure rates. See the section on How should I assess a woman who is considering using Natural Family Planning methods in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.
  • The Family Planning Association provides a useful leaflet, Your guide to natural family planning, which has information for users of the LAM (and other methods of contraception).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on expert opinion in a medical textbook, The essentials of contraceptive technology: a handbook for clinic staff [Hatcher et al, 1997].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the advantages, disadvantages, and risks of using the lactational amenorrhoea method of contraception?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Advantages
  • Lactational amenorrhoea can be effective for up to 6 months.
  • It encourages exclusive breastfeeding up to 6 months.
  • It can be used immediately after childbirth.
  • There is no need to do anything at the time of sexual intercourse.
  • There is no direct cost, as it requires no supplies or procedures.
  • It has no hormonal adverse effects.
  • Counselling for the method encourages starting a follow-on method at the proper time.
  • It does not involve abstinence from sexual intercourse.
Disadvantages
  • The lactational amenorrhoea method does not protect against sexually transmitted infections, including HIV.
  • It becomes unreliable after 6 months and when other foods (including infant milk formula) are introduced into the baby's diet.
  • Frequent breastfeeding is inconvenient or difficult for some women.
[Hatcher et al, 1997]

subChapters.htmlHeader: How effective is the lactational amenorrhoea method at preventing pregnancy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
For comparison of the efficacy of the lactational amenorrhoea method with other methods of contraception, see the section on Comparative efficacy of contraceptive methods in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment. 

  • When used perfectly (consistently and correctly) 0.5% of women will conceive during the first 6 months after childbirth due to method failure.
  • When used typically, 2% of women will conceive during the first 6 months after childbirth due to method failure or user failure.

[Hatcher, 2011; FSRH, 2015]
